{{Other uses}} {{Original research|date=March 2010}} A '''happy ending''' is an ending of the [[Plot (narrative)|plot]] of a work of [[fiction]] in which almost everything turns out for the best for the [[protagonists]], their [[sidekick]]s, and almost everyone except the [[villain]]s.
In storylines where the protagonists are in physical [[Risk|danger]], a happy ending mainly consists of their survival and successful completion of the [[quest]] or mission; where there is no physical danger, a happy ending may be lovers [[Consummation|consummating]] their love despite various factors which may have thwarted it. A considerable number of storylines combine both situations. In [[Steven Spielberg]]'s version of "[[War of the Worlds (2005 film)|War of the Worlds]]", the happy ending consists of three distinct elements: The protagonists all survive the countless perils of their journey; humanity as a whole survives the alien invasion; ''and'' the protagonist father regains the respect of his estranged children. The plot is so constructed that all three are needed for the audience's feeling of satisfaction in the end.
A happy ending is epitomized in the standard [[fairy tale]] ending phrase, "'''happily ever after'''" or "and they lived happily ever after". (''[[One Thousand and One Nights]]'' has the more restrained formula "they lived happily until there came to them the One who Destroys all Happiness" (i.e. Death); likewise, the Russian versions of fairy tales typically end with "they lived long and happily, and died together on the same day".) Satisfactory happy endings are happy for the reader as well, in that the characters he or she sympathizes with are rewarded. However, this can also serve as an open path for a possible sequel. For example, in the 1977 film ''[[Star Wars (film)|Star Wars]]'', [[Luke Skywalker]] defeats the [[Galactic Empire (Star Wars)|Galactic Empire]] by destroying the [[Death Star]]; however, the story's happy ending has consequences that follow in ''[[The Empire Strikes Back]]''. The concept of a permanent happy ending is specifically brought up in the [[Stephen King]] fantasy/fairy tale novel ''[[The Eyes of the Dragon]]'' which has a standard good ending for the genre, but simply states that "there were good days and bad days" afterwards.
==Features== A happy ending only requires that the main characters be all right. Millions of innocent background characters can die, but as long as the characters that the reader/viewer/audience cares about survive, it can still be a happy ending. [[Roger Ebert]] comments in his review of [[Roland Emmerich]]'s ''[[The Day After Tomorrow]]'': "Billions of people may have died, but at least the major characters have survived. Los Angeles is leveled by multiple tornadoes, New York is buried under ice and snow, the United Kingdom is flash-frozen, and lots of the Northern Hemisphere is wiped out for good measure. Thank god that Jack, Sam, Laura, Jason and Dr. Lucy Hall survive, along with Dr. Hall's little [[cancer]] patient."<ref>[http://rogerebert.suntimes.com/apps/pbcs.dll/article?AID=/20040528/REVIEWS/405280303/1023 Ebert's review of ''The Day After Tomorrow'']</ref>
==Examples== ===William Shakespeare=== The presence of a happy ending is one of the key points that distinguish [[melodrama]] from [[tragedy]]. In certain periods, the endings of traditional tragedies such as ''[[Macbeth]]'' or ''[[Oedipus Rex]]'', in which most of the major characters end up dead, disfigured, or discountenanced, have been actively disliked. In the Seventeenth Century, the Irish author [[Nahum Tate]] sought to improve [[William Shakespeare]]'s ''[[King Lear]]'' in [[The History of King Lear|his own heavily modified version]] in which Lear survives and Cordelia marries Edgar. Tate's version dominated performances for a century and a half, Shakespeare's original nearly forgotten. Both [[David Garrick]] and [[John Philip Kemble]], while taking up some of Shakespeare's original text, kept Tate's happy ending. [[Edmund Kean]] played ''King Lear'' with its tragic ending in 1823, but failed and reverted to Tate's crowd-pleaser after only three performances. Only in 1838 did [[William Macready]] at Covent Garden successfully restore Shakespeare's original tragic end – [[Helena Faucit|Helen Faucit]]'s final appearance as Cordelia, dead in her father's arms, became one of the most iconic of Victorian images and the play's tragic end was finally accepted by the general public. Most subsequent critics have not found Tate's amendments an improvement, and welcomed the restoration of Shakespeare's original. Happy endings have also been fastened – equally, with no lasting success – to ''[[Romeo and Juliet]]'' and ''[[Othello]]''.
There is no universally accepted definition of what a happy ending is; such definitions can considerably vary with time and cultural differences. An interpretation of ''[[The Merchant of Venice]]''{{'}}s forced conversion of [[Shylock]] to Christianity is that it was intended as a happy ending. As a Christian, Shylock could no longer impose interest, undoing his schemes in the play and ending the rivalry between him and Antonio, but more important, contemporary audiences would see becoming a Christian as a means to save his soul (cf. [[Epistle to the Romans|Romans]] 11:15). In later times, Jews (and non-Jewish opponents of anti-Semitism) strongly objected to that ending, regarding it as depicting a victory for injustice and oppression and as pandering to the audience's prejudices.
===Don Juan===
Most interpretations of the [[legend]] of [[Don Juan]] end with the protagonist [[Rake (stock character)|rake]] being dragged off to [[Hell]], in just retribution for his many sins (for example, the ending of [[Mozart]]'s ''[[Don Giovanni]]''). However, [[José Zorrilla]] - whose 1844 [[Play (theatre)|play]] ''[[Don Juan Tenorio]]'' is the version most well-known in the Spanish-speaking world - believed that a story should never end sadly, and must always have a happy ending. In Zorrilla's depiction, Don Juan is saved at the last moment from the flames of Hell by the selfless pure love of Doña Inés, a woman whom he wronged but who forgave him; she had made a deal with God to offer her own blameless soul on behalf of Don Juan's - thus redeeming Don Juan and taking him with her to [[Paradise]].
===Novels=== A ''[[The Times|Times]]'' review of ''[[The Spy Who Came in from the Cold]]'' strongly criticized [[John le Carré]] for failing to provide a happy ending, and gave unequivocal reasons why in the reviewer's opinion (shared by many others) such an ending is needed: "''The hero must triumph over his enemies, as surely as [[Jack and the Beanstalk|Jack]] must kill the giant in the nursery tale. If the giant kills Jack, we have missed the whole point of the story.''"<ref>''[[The Times]]'', September 13, 1968.</ref>
[[George Bernard Shaw]] had to wage an uphill struggle against audiences, as well as some critics, persistently demanding that his "[[Pygmalion (play)#Ending|Pygmalion]]" have a happy ending, i.e. that Professor Higgins and Eliza Doolitle would ultimately get married.<ref>Evans, T.F. (ed.) (1997). ''George Bernard Shaw (The Critical Heritage Series).'' {{ISBN|0-415-15953-9}}, pp. 223–30.</ref><ref>"From the Point of View of A Playwright," by Bernard Shaw, collected in ''Herbert Beerbohm Tree, Some Memories of Him and His Art, Collected by Max Beerbohm'' (1919). London: Hutchinson. [https://archive.org/details/herbertbeerbohmt00beer Versions at Text Archive] [https://archive.org/about/about.php Internet Archive]<!--Retrieved from http://archive.org November 2[[3, 2009.--></ref> To Shaw's great chagrin, [[Herbert Beerbohm Tree]] who presented the play in London's [[West End theatre|West End]] in 1914 had sweetened the ending and told Shaw: "My ending makes money; you ought to be grateful. Your ending is damnable; you ought to be shot."<ref>Shaw, Bernard, edited by Dan H. Laurence. Collected Letters vol. III: 1911–1925.</ref> The irritated Shaw added a postscript essay, "'What Happened Afterwards",<ref>Shaw, G.B. (1916). ''Pygmalion''. New York: Brentano. [http://www.bartleby.com/138/6.html Sequel: What Happened Afterwards.] [http://www.bartleby.com/sv/welcome.html Bartleby: Great Books Online.]</ref> to the 1916 print edition, for inclusion with subsequent editions, in which he explained precisely why in his view it was impossible for the story to end with Higgins and Eliza getting married. Nevertheless, audiences continued wanting a happy ending also for later adaptations such as the musical and film "[[My Fair Lady]]".
===Hollywood films===
In numerous cases, [[Hollywood]] studios adapting literary works into film added a happy ending which did not appear in the original. * [[Mary Shelley]]'s 1818 novel, ''[[Frankenstein]]'', ended with the deaths of [[Victor Frankenstein]] and [[Elizabeth Lavenza]]. In the [[Frankenstein (1931 film)|1931 film adaption]] they survive and marry. * [[C. S. Forester]]'s 1935 novel ''[[The African Queen (novel)|The African Queen]]'' has a British couple, stranded in Africa during the [[First World War]], hatch a plot to sink a German gunboat; they make an enormous, dedicated struggle, with boundless effort and sacrifice, but at the last moment their quest ends with failure and futility. In the [[The African Queen (film)|1951 film adaptation]] they succeed, and get to see the German boat sink (just in time to save them from being hanged by the Germans). * [[Truman Capote]]'s [[1958 in literature|1958]] [[novella]] ''[[Breakfast at Tiffany's (novella)|Breakfast at Tiffany's]]'' ended with the main character, Holly Golightly, going her own solitary way and disappearing from the male protagonist's life. In the 1961 [[Breakfast at Tiffany's (film)| film made on its base]] she finally accepts the love he offers her and the film ends with their warmly embracing, oblivious of a pouring rain. * [[Hans Christian Andersen]]'s [[fairy tale]] ''[[The Little Mermaid]]'' ends with the protagonist mermaid making a noble sacrifice, resigned to seeing her beloved prince marrying another woman. In the 1989 [[The Little Mermaid (1989 film)| Disney adaptation]], the mermaid does get to happily marry her prince. Disney later added [[The Little Mermaid II: Return to the Sea |a sequel]], obviously impossible for the Andersen original, focused on the child born of that marriage.
==See also== * [[Eucatastrophe]] * [[Once upon a time]]

'''The Ho-Am Prize''' was established in 1990 by [[Lee Kun-hee|Kun-Hee Lee]], the Chairman of [[Samsung]], with a vision to create a new corporate culture that continues the noble spirit of public service espoused by the late Chairman Byung-chull Lee, founder of Samsung<ref>{{cite web |url=http://hoamprize.samsungfoundation.org/eng/foundation/intro.asp |title= The HO-AM Prize |publisher= Smsung |accessdate=3 November 2013}}</ref>
Awarded since 1991, it is funded by [[Samsung]] and named after their former chairman, [[Lee Byung-chul]] (Ho-Am is his pen name which means ''filling up a space with clear water as lakes do, and being unshakeable as a large rock'').
The Ho-Am Prize is currently awarded in five fields: Science, Engineering, Medicine, Arts and Community Service.
Winners of the '''[[Ho-Am Prize]] in the Arts''', established in 1994, include :
Source: [http://hoamprize.samsungfoundation.org/eng/award/part.asp HoAm]
* 1994: [[Won-Yong Kim]] * 1995: [[Nam June Paik]] * 1996: [[Kyung-Ree Park]] * 1997: [[Myung-Whun Chung]] * 1998: [[Myung Hee Choi]] * 1999: [[Munyol Yi]] * 2000: [[Kun-Woo Paik]] * 2001: [[Lee Ufan]] * 2002: [[Sue Jin Kang]] * 2003: [[Im Kwon Taek]] * 2004: [[Byung-Ki Hwang]] * 2005: [[Oh Tae-Sok]] * 2006: [[Wan-Suh Park]] * 2007: [[Yi Chong-jun]] * 2008: [[Kyu Sung Woo]] * 2009: [[Shin Kyeong-nim]] * 2010: [[Min-Ho Chang]] * 2011: [[Kyung-Wha Chung]] * 2012: [[Unsuk Chin]] * 2013: [[Shin Kyung-sook]] * 2014: [[Hei-Kyung Hong]] * 2015: [[Kimsooja]] * 2016: [[Tong-gyu Hwang]] * 2017: [[Do-ho Suh]] * 2018: [[Kwangchul Youn]]
==See also== * [[Ho-Am Prize]] * [[Ho-Am Prize in Science]] * [[Ho-Am Prize in Engineering]] * [[Ho-Am Prize in Medicine]] * [[Ho-Am Prize in Community Service]]
== References == {{reflist}}
{{Samsung}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Ho-Am Prize In The Arts}}

{{Infobox writer <!-- for more information see [[:Template:Infobox writer/doc]] --> | name = J. N. Williamson | image = | caption = | pseudonym = | birth_date = {{birth date|1932|4|17}} | birth_name = | birth_place = [[Indianapolis]], [[Indiana]], United States | death_date = {{death date and age|2005|12|8|1932|4|17}} | death_place = [[Noblesville, Indiana]], United States | occupation = Novelist, short story writer, editor, journalist | language = English | period = | genre = [[Horror novel|Horror]], [[fantasy]], [[science fiction]], [[Gothic fiction|gothic]], [[dark fantasy]] | movement = | notableworks = | awards = | website = | spouse = | children = | alma_mater = [[Butler University]] }}
'''Gerald "Jerry" Neal Williamson''' (April 17, 1932 - December 8, 2005) was an American horror writer and editor known under the name '''J. N. Williamson'''.<ref name=G>{{cite book|pages=129–134|date=2003|publisher=[[Wildside Press]]|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=9Rq7nCRyvb0C&pg=PT115&lpg=PT115&dq=They+Never+Even+See+Me+JN+williamson&source=bl&ots=pygGNXlyIE&sig=Rl-zqqG7jjdzi1zBMgCcl-Qfejo&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0CDsQ6AEwBWoVChMItMCX6dWHyQIVRthjCh22CAUP#v=onepage&q=They%20Never%20Even%20See%20Me%20JN%20williamson&f=false|title=Giants of the Genre: Interviews with Science Fiction, Fantasy, and Horror's Greatest Talents|author=McCarty, Michael}}</ref><ref>[http://www.fearnet.com/news/review/graphic-novel-review-jn-williamsons-illustrated-masques Fearnet.com]</ref><ref>[http://www.themidnightdiner.com/a-modest-history-of-horror-j-n-williamson/ Themidnightdiner.com]</ref><ref>[http://www.locusmag.com/2005/News/2005NewsArchive.html Locusmag.com]</ref><ref>[http://www.sff.net/people/lucy-snyder/brain/2005/12/jn-williamson-biography-and.html Sff.net]</ref><ref>[http://www.fantasticfiction.co.uk/w/j-n-williamson/ Fantasticfiction.co.uk]</ref> Born in [[Indianapolis, Indiana]] he graduated from [[Shortridge High School]]. He studied journalism at [[Butler University]]. He published his first novel in 1979 and went on to publish more than 40 novels and 150 short stories. In 2003 he received a lifetime achievement award from the [[Horror Writers of America]]. He edited the critically acclaimed ''How to Write Tales of Horror, Fantasy & Science Fiction (1987)'' which covered the themes of such writing and cited the writings of such writers as [[Robert Bloch]], Lee Prosser, [[Richard Matheson]], [[Ray Bradbury]], [[H. P. Lovecraft]], [[August Derleth]], [[William F. Nolan]], and [[Stephen King]]. Many important writers in the genre contributed to the book. Williamson edited the popular anthology series, ''Masques''. Some of his novels include ''The Ritual (1979)'', ''Playmates (1982)'', ''Noonspell (1991)'', ''The Haunt (1999)'', among others.
Williamson recalled in a 2003 interview that his first work of fiction was a [[Sherlock Holmes]] [[pastiche]] called "The Terrible Death of Crosby, The Banker."<ref name=G/>
==Bibliography==
===Series===
===Martin Ruben=== * ''The Ritual'' (1979) * ''Premonition'' (1981) * ''Brotherkind'' (1982)
===Lamia Zacharias=== * ''Death-Coach'' (1981) * ''Death-Angel'' (1981) * ''Death-School'' (1982) * ''Death-Doctor'' (1982)
===Novels=== * ''The Offspring'' (1980) * ''The Tulpa'' (1980) * ''Horror House'' (1981) * ''The Banished'' (1981) * ''Ghost Mansion'' (1981) * ''Queen of Hell'' (1981) * ''The Evil One'' (1981) * ''Playmates'' (1982) * ''Extraterrestrial'' (1982) (writing as Julian Shock) * ''Horror Mansion'' (1982) * ''Nevermore'' (1983) * ''The Hour'' (1983) * ''The Dentist'' (1983) * ''Ghost'' (1984) * ''Babel's Children'' (1984) * ''The Longest Night'' (1985) * ''Ladies of the Longest Night'' (1985) * ''Wards of Armageddon'' (1986) (with John Maclay) * ''The Houngan'' (1987) * ''Evil Offspring'' (1987) * ''Noonspell'' (1987) * ''Dead to the World'' (1988) * ''They Never Even See Me'' (1989) * ''The Black School'' (1989) * ''Shadows of Death'' (1989) * ''Hell Storm'' (1990) * ''The Night Seasons'' (1991) * ''The Monastery'' (1992) * ''Don't Take Away the Light'' (1993) * ''The Book of Webster's'' (1993) * ''Bloodlines'' (1994) * ''Spree'' (1998) * ''The Haunt'' (1999) * ''Affinity'' (2001)
===Collections=== * ''The New Devil's Dictionary: Creepy Cliches and Sinister Synonyms'' (1985) * ''The Naked Flesh of Feeling'' (1991) * ''The Fifth Season'' (1994) * ''Frights of Fancy'' (2000)
===Anthologies=== * ''Masques: All-New Works of Horror and the Supernatural'' (1984) * ''Masques 2'' (1987) * ''The Best of Masques'' (1988) * ''Masques 3'' (1989) * ''Flesh Creepers'' (1990) * ''Masques 4'' (1991) * ''Dark Masques'' (2001) * ''Darker Masques'' (2002) * ''Masques V'' (2006)
===Short stories=== * ''House Mothers'' (1984) * ''The Gap Nearly Closed Today'' (1985) * ''The Book of Webster's'' (1986) * ''The Night Seasons'' (1986) * ''Privacy Rights'' (1987) * ''Wordsong'' (1987) * ''Fancy That'' (1988) * ''Overnight Pass'' (1989) (with John Maclay) * ''Monstrum'' (1989) * ''Stories for All Seasons'' (1989) * ''The Sudd'' (1989) * ''The Unkindest Cut'' (1989) * ''You'd Better Watch Out'' (1989) * ''The Bridge People'' (1990) * ''Happier Endings'' (1990) * ''Something Extra'' (1990) (with James Kisner) * ''Frankenstein Seen in the Ice of Extinction'' (1993) * ''Goddam Time'' (1993) (with Scott Fogel) * ''Reality Function'' (1993) * ''Beasts in Buildings, Turning 'Round'' (1995) * ''High Concept'' (1995) * ''The Last Link Between Life and Death'' (1995) * ''Origin of a Species'' (1995) * ''Vladimir's Conversions'' (1995) * ''Hildekin and the Big Diehl'' (1996) * ''Two Hands Are Better Than One'' (1996) * ''It Does Not Come Along'' (1997)
===Non fiction=== * ''How to Write Tales of Horror, Fantasy and Science Fiction'' (1987)
===Anthologies containing stories by J. N. Williamson=== * ''Masques: All New Works of Horror and the Supernatural'' (1984) * ''Best of the Horror Show: An Adventure in Terror'' (1987) * ''Masques 2'' (1987) * ''Whispers VI'' (1987) * ''Fantasy Tales: Vol. 10 - No. 1'' (1988) * ''Hot Blood: Tales of Provocative Horror'' (1989) * ''Masques 3'' (1989) * ''Scare Care'' (1989) * ''Urban Horrors'' (1990) * ''The Year's Best Fantasy and Horror Third Annual Collection'' (1990) * ''Hotter Blood: More Tales of Erotic Horror'' (1991) * ''100 Ghastly Little Ghost Stories'' (1992) * ''Dark Seductions: Tales of Erotic Horror'' (1993) * ''Frankenstein: The Monster Wakes'' (1993) * ''Monsters in Our Midst'' (1993) * ''Predators'' (1993) * ''Celebrity Vampires'' (1995) * ''Night Screams'' (1995) * ''Seeds of Fear'' (1995) * ''Vampire Detectives'' (1995) * ''Werewolves'' (1995) * ''Fear the Fever'' (1996) * ''The Giant Book of Fantasy Tales'' (1996) * ''White House Horrors'' (1996) * ''Terminal Frights'' (1997)

'''Jim Sévellec'''<ref>Nickname he was given by Scottish or American troops during the First World War, as easier to pronounce than Eugène - {{Cite web | url = http://www.wiki-brest.net/index.php/S%C3%A9vellec,_Jim | title = Rue Jim Sévellec | author = Filyg, Jeffdelonge | publisher = Wiki-Brest | accessdate=2008-07-29 }} </ref><ref>He generally signed himself '''Jim E. Sévellec'''</ref>(21 January 1897 - 21 May 1971), born '''Eugène Sévellec''', was a French painter.
==Life== Eugène Sévellec was born at [[Camaret-sur-Mer]]. He grew up in an artistic colony around [[Symbolist]] [[poet]] [[Saint-Pol-Roux]] and drew the life of the port whilst very young. Under the influence of the Saint-Pol-Roux, he left for Paris to train under painter [[Louis-Marie Désiré-Lucas]]. <ref>{{Cite web | url = http://www.lexpress.fr/region/la-peinture-dans-le-sang_480450.html | title = Les Sevellec - La peinture dans le sang | author = Bruno D. Cot | date = created 21 September 2006 - published 25 September 2003 | work = L'Express.fr | accessdate=2008-07-29 }} </ref> From 1916 he was mobilised in the infantry and served among others as an interpreter for American and Scottish troops. From 1928 he collaborated with the Henriot factiory, a [[Faïence de Quimper|faïencerie de Quimper]]. <ref>{{Cite web | url = http://quimper-encheres.site.voila.fr/page4.html | title = Biographie Sévellec | author = Marc-Antoine Ruzette | date = January 2005 | publisher = Quimper Enchères | accessdate=2008-07-30 }} </ref>
In 1936 he was made [[peintre de la Marine]]. <ref>{{Cite web | url = http://www.defense.gouv.fr/marine/base/dossiers/dossier_les_peintres_de_la_marine/liste_des_peintres_depuis_1830__1 | title = List of painters since 1830 | publisher = Marine Nationale | accessdate=2008-07-30 }} {{Dead link|date=October 2010|bot=H3llBot}} </ref>
He also created dioramas of [[Brest, France]] for the Musée de la [[Tour Tanguy]]. <ref>{{Cite web | url = http://www.mairie-brest.fr/brest/tour_tanguy.htm | title = Le Musée de la Tour Tanguy | publisher = Ville de Brest | accessdate=2008-07-30 |archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20080417014426/http://www.mairie-brest.fr/brest/tour_tanguy.htm <!-- Bot retrieved archive --> |archivedate = 17 April 2008}} </ref>
He died at [[Brest, France]].
==Works== *''Brest : Son histoire et son rôle dans la vie de la Basse-Bretagne'', Jim and Joël Sévellec, Brest, 1955
==Notes== {{Reflist}}
{{Use dmy dates|date=September 2010}}

[[File:RadfordArms.png|thumb|200px|Arms of Radford of [[Radford, Plymstock|Radford]]: ''Sable, three [[lampago]]es passant coward in pale argent''<ref>[[William Pole (antiquary)|Pole, Sir William]] (d.1635), Collections Towards a Description of the County of Devon, [[Sir John de la Pole, 6th Baronet|Sir John-William de la Pole]] (ed.), London, 1791, p.499: "Radford of Radford: Sable, 3 lampagoes, [man tygers, with lion's bodyes and men's faces] passant [in pale] cowarde argent"</ref>]] A '''lampago''' is a mythical heraldic beast in the form of a "man-tiger or man-lion" with the body of a tiger or lion and the head of a man.<ref>[[William Pole (antiquary)|Pole, Sir William]] (d.1635), Collections Towards a Description of the County of Devon, [[Sir John de la Pole, 6th Baronet|Sir John-William de la Pole]] (ed.), London, 1791, p.499, blazon of arms of "Radford of Radford": ''Sable, three lampagoes (man tygers, with lion's bodys and men's faces) passant in pale coward argent''"</ref> It should be distinguished from similar mythical heraldic beasts the [[manticore]] and the [[satyral]].<ref>Dennys, Rodney, The Heraldic Imagination. London: Barrie & Jenkins, 1975, p.114</ref>
The best-known usage of the lampago in heraldry is in the arms of the ancient Radford family of the manor of [[Radford, Plymstock|Radford]] in the parish of [[Plymstock]] in Devon: ''Sable, three lampagoes passant in pale coward argent''.<ref>Pole, p.499</ref>

revision.text:
{{EngvarB|date=July 2014}} {{Use dmy dates|date=July 2014}} {{Infobox artist | bgcolour = | name = Lin Hsin Hsin
林欣欣 | image = | caption = | imagesize = | birth_name = | birth_date = | birth_place = Singapore | death_date = | death_place = | nationality = {{SIN}} | field = Mathematics, [[Computer Science]], Information Technology, Color Science, [[Digital Art]], [[Digital Music]], [[Digital Media]], poetry | years_active = | training = | movement = | works = | patrons = | influenced by = | influenced = | awards = | website = [http://www.lhham.com.sg/ www.lhham.com.sg] }} '''Lin Hsin Hsin''' ({{zh|s=林欣欣|p= Lín Xīn Xīn}}) is an IT inventor, artist, poet and composer from Singapore, deeply rooted in mathematics and information technology.Nor-Afidah Abd, [http://infopedia.nlb.gov.sg/articles/SIP_302_2005-01-07.html Lin Hsin Hsin] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20070612170325/http://infopedia.nlb.gov.sg/articles/SIP_302_2005-01-07.html |date=12 June 2007 }}, [[Infopedia]], Singapore, 27 May 2003. She established the first [[virtual museum]] website, the [[Lin Hsin Hsin Art Museum]], in 1994.[http://www.archimuse.com/mw97/speak/hsinbio.htm Lin Hsin Hsin — Speaker biography] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110527151155/http://www.archimuse.com/mw97/speak/hsinbio.htm |date=27 May 2011 }}, ''[[Museums and the Web]]'', 1997. ==Background== Lin was born in Singapore. She graduated in mathematics from the [[University of Singapore]] and received a postgraduate degree in [[computer science]] from [[Newcastle University]], England. She studied music and art in Singapore,[http://nationalartgallery.sg/exhibition-events/csp/the-exhibition/research-and-critical-essay/ An Essay, 2010] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110909041813/http://nationalartgallery.sg/exhibition-events/csp/the-exhibition/research-and-critical-essay/ |date=9 September 2011 }} [[printmaking]] at the [[University of Ulster]], [[papermaking]] in [[Ogawamachi]], Japan and [[paper conservation]] at the [[University of Melbourne]] Conservation Services. ==IT Invention & IT Visionary== Lin Hsin Hsin is a [[digital native]]. Lin builds paradigm shift & patent-grade [[invention]]s. She is an IT visionary some 20 years ahead of time, who pens her IT vision in computing, poems, and paintings. === IT Visionary === * 1999 February 16, poem titled "entrepreneur" on [[entrepreneur]], p. 21, "Between the Lines" * 1999 February 16, poem titled "e-commerce" on [[e-commerce]], p. 21, "In Bytes We Travel" * 1999 February 1, poem titled "Mobility" on [[mobile computing|mobility]], p. 20, "Between the Lines" * 1996 October, predicted [[Twitter]], tweeting as a way of life. in a [[diptych]] titled "twigee-tweedee", [[digital art]] in private collection, [[Paris]], [[France]] * 1996 October 1, poem titled "e-money" on [[digital currency]] & [[Cryptocurrency]] p. 58, "In Bytes We Travel" * 1995 September 9, poem titled "The Day Will Come..." on SMS, using fingers to type on screen, p. 181, "In Bytes We Travel" * 1995 September 9, poem titled "Virtual Offices" predicted [[virtual office]] as the concept of businesses, p. 20, "In Bytes We Travel" * 1995 September 5, poem titled "take a walk thru' the cyber mall", on [[e-commerce]], p. 54, "In Bytes WeTravel" * 1994 Designed and built first [[virtual museum]] in the world,"Virtual Museum Tour – from Reality to Fantasy Singaporehttps://lhham.com.sg/AI/Lin-Hsin-Hsin-AI-SG.html ==Contemporary Art== ===Paintings and sculptures=== Lin Hsin Hsin specialises in [[oil painting]], she has transformed the opaque properties of [[oil paint]] to make it [[translucent]] in 1988."Modern Art in Singapore", Actuell DB, [[Deutsche Bank]] AG, [[Frankfurt]], August 1989"Kunst-Sponsoring durch Banken – Das Beispiel des Kunstkonzepts der Deutsche Bank AG", Prof Dr. Hans E. Büschgen, Vortrag beim 11. Churburger Wirtschaftsgespräch am 12 Oct 1996 As such, she has made oil paint to look like [[watercolor]], [[Chinese ink]] as well as [[pastel]], [[pencil]] or [[charcoal]], as demonstrated in the Aqua Series"The awesome power of water", Straits Times, 30 June 1989"Water, water, everywhere", Business Times, 3 July 1989"Using Oil to convey a message", Straits Times, 4 July 1989 of paintings. Besides oil paintings, she makes [[Acrylic resin|acrylic]] sculptures. ===Art Exhibitions=== Lin Hsin Hsin has held 15 solo exhibitions in Singapore, [[Amsterdam]],Adformatie, 18de jaargang No. 16, 1990Uitkrant, jaargang 24 No. 8, April 1990Alert, 6e jaargang No. 5, 1990 and [[San Jose, California]], United States. She has participated in more than 220 exhibitions in 60 cities, 26 countries across Asia, Europe,"Feinsinning und Züruckhaltend", Mannheimer Morgen, 16 July 1990"Jedem eine Chance und eine Roje", [[Frankfurter Allgemeine Zeitung]], Dezember 15, 1990"Ein Hauch Fernost in der Bank", Neue Rheine Zeitung, März 6, 1990"Die Kunst der Assimilation", [[Handelsblatt]], März 9/10, 1990"Am Schnittpunkt zwischen West und Ost", Rheinische Post, März 13, 1990"Kunst aus dem Fernen Osten", Forum, Deutsche Bank AG, Frankfurt, No. 2, April 1990 North America and South America."Hsin Hsin's work for [[Chile]]", Straits Times, 8 September 1989, p.4 {{cite web |url=http://newspapers.nl.sg/Digitised/Article.aspx?articleid=straitstimes19890908.2.74.5.5.1&sessionid=4bbdb2e84c6e43b1a64c462c9e775d2d&keyword=Lin+Hsin |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2011-05-31 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20121107040537/http://newspapers.nl.sg/Digitised/Article.aspx?articleid=straitstimes19890908.2.74.5.5.1&sessionid=4bbdb2e84c6e43b1a64c462c9e775d2d&keyword=Lin+Hsin |archivedate=7 November 2012 |df=dmy-all }} ===Art Collectors=== Lin's art can be seen in private, public and museum collections in 32 cities across Asia, Europe, North America and Australia. In 1985, she was awarded a silver medal by the [[Société des Artistes Français]], Paris. In 1987, Lin received the [[IBM]] Singapore Art Award, she has received Visiting Fellowship to Germany in 1988 and [[Japan Foundation]] Fellowship in 1991 Her artworks are in private, public and museum collections in Asia, Europe and North America. ===Paper=== Besides paper sculptures, [[papier collé]], [[collograph]] and monoprints, Lin handmade [[acid-free paper]]."Washi Paper", Japan Topic, Japan Information & Culture Center, Embassy of Japan, December 1991 She has pioneered acid-free [[papaya]] paper"Artist fashions artwork made from papaya tree", The Straits Times, 8 June 1993 {{cite web |url=http://newspapers.nl.sg/Digitised/Article.aspx?articleid=straitstimes19930610.2.37.7&sessionid=8a575ff2768942b0afc61ceb5c621cc0&keyword=Lin+Hsin+Hsin&lang=en |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2011-05-31 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20121107040412/http://newspapers.nl.sg/Digitised/Article.aspx?articleid=straitstimes19930610.2.37.7&sessionid=8a575ff2768942b0afc61ceb5c621cc0&keyword=Lin+Hsin+Hsin&lang=en |archivedate=7 November 2012 |df=dmy-all }} and [[Cyperus alternifolius|umbrella plant]] paper in 1992"Beauty in Fiber", p. 77, Sali'ng Lahat Saling Tanggap—A Report on the ASEAN Conference and Workshop, Manila Philippines, 24 May 1993 . ==Digital Media== ===Digital Media Pioneer=== Lin is a digital media pioneer,"Lin Hsin Hsin – A Multimedia Artist in the Garden City", p. 146, Digital Boy (with CD-ROM), Tokyo, Japan, May 1996 She has created [[digital music]] in 1985, 3D [[digital art]] in 1987, and digital animation in 1989 in Singapore. Since 1993 todate, Lin has pioneered the use of a two-button mechanical [[PC Mouse]] to [[Drawing|draw]] and [[paint]] Western and [[Chinese paintings]]. [http://newspapers.nl.sg/Digitised/Article.aspx?articleid=straitstimes19971128.2.169.2.2&sessionid=6adfb4d4908644d7a44716931b075542&keyword=Lin+Hsin+Hsin&lang=en “She paints with a mouse”, Straits Times, 28 November 1997, p.3] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20121107040443/http://newspapers.nl.sg/Digitised/Article.aspx?articleid=straitstimes19971128.2.169.2.2&sessionid=6adfb4d4908644d7a44716931b075542&keyword=Lin+Hsin+Hsin&lang=en |date=7 November 2012 }} She has created digital [[oil paintings]], [[watercolors]], Chinese [[ink]] paintings and calligraphy. She also digitally sketches with this mouse. Hsin Hsin has never and does not use any [[tablet computer|tablet PC]] and [[stylus]] in such creation. moved into the digital world. However, Lin has, since 1994, began with the digital, and fabricated the digital into the real Lin Hsin Hsin created [[Web art]]{{cite web |url=http://www.virtual-worlds.net/vw98/hsin.htm |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2011-06-18 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120325205538/http://www.virtual-worlds.net/vw98/hsin.htm |archivedate=25 March 2012 |df=dmy-all }} and [[Net art]] in 1995, [[HTML]] art in 1996 and she has developed [[interactive Web art]]"CyberKunst aus Singapur" Wirtschafts Woche, 24 Februar, 2000 since 1997. Lin pioneered virtual sculpting in 1999 in Singapore; it was exhibited in Paris, France in 1999, 2001, and 2003. ===ISM=== Lin believes in Mathematical & Computing fundamentals, she anchors on science to create art. She * forbids drag & drop, scan & morph, cut & paste processes to create digital art. * established Eco-computing[http://dblp.l3s.de/Topics/eco-computing&rrc=92 "eco-computing" – FacetedDBLP"] initiatives for digital media in 2007. * algorithm driven & equation-based * Linux platform ===Genres=== Lin initiates, establishes and creates different genres of digital art: * Non-Photorealistic She built and launched an Emoji City, September 12, 2016. ====BLOCKMOJI==== Lin initiates and creates different genres of blockmoji -- An emoji genre for [[blockchain]], both still and animated. She launched Blockmoji, August 8, 2018. ==Music== ===Digital music=== From conceptualisation to composing, from sound calibration to mastering, Lin has produced music on a PC without a sound card and midi instruments. Lin creates virtual instruments including a virtual [[didgeridoo]], a [[berimbau]] used by the [[Brazilian people|Brazilian]] aborigines. In 2006, Lin has realised the [[sonification]] of nature, including a [[rainforest]], [[waterfalls]] and wind by an interactive virtual [[sound board (music)|sound board]] she has created. Hsin Hsin's music has been performed in [[Vienna]], [[Austria]] in 2002, [[Bourges]], France in 2003, 2004 and [[Pisa]], Italy, 2005. ===Music visualisation=== Lin has composed music and painted music as an artist. The 45 paintings in the "Abstraction in Music" Series (1986–1987) is her interpretation of music on canvas, as she is moved by the music of great composers such as [[Handel]] ([[Water Music (Handel)|Water Music]]), [[Mozart]] ([[Jupiter Symphony]]), [[Franz Liszt]] (Rhapsodies dan l'espace), [[Vivaldi]] ([[The Four Seasons (Vivaldi)|The Four Seasons]]), [[Debussy]] ([[La Mer (Debussy)|La Mer]]). In addition to the [[canvases]], there are the paperworks subtitled "''La Petite Séries''" created with different techniques, an abstraction of audio visualisation—perceived images of the sound in music such as Musical Ornaments: [[Trill (music)|Trill]], [[Appoggiatura]] and [[Turn (music)|Turn]] ([[Staccato]]) and sound in the universe like [[Woodpecker]]. Lin has conceptualised and written about the art in music and music in art. Since 2002, Hsin Hsin has digitally created [[visual music]], or [[animated music]], as she puts it. 2005, Lin built wearables and lights that response to music. 2006, Lin built paradigm shift interactive digital real-world musical instruments—I-Musika[http://portal.acm.org/citation.cfm?id=1271614 I1)-Musika:Mobile Interface Musical Expression (MIME)] IV '07 Proceedings of the 11th International Conference Information Visualization, {{ISBN|0-7695-2900-3}} [http://doi.ieeecomputersociety.org/10.1109/IV.2007.67] ===Interactive music=== Lin developed an interactive Music Sound Board in 2006. The creation of this soft sound board enables real time creation of the sound of nature. Examples are elements of sound audible in nature, such as [[rain forest]], insects, water, and wind. ==Intermedia== Combining mathematics, technology, art and music, Hsin Hsin pursues [[interdisciplinary]] studies. == Poetry == Lin speaks, reads and writes in [[Chinese language|Chinese]], [[English language|English]], [[Japanese language|Japanese]] and [[French language|French]]. Calder]][http://newspapers.nl.sg/Digitised/Article.aspx?articleid=straitstimes19861207.2.95.16.2&sessionid=14a6d6fe33f1494a960b136026f299f7&keyword=Lin+Hsin+Hsin&lang=en The man who made sculpture available @ Computer Science Bibliographic Repository[http://www.informatik.uni-trier.de/~ley/db/indices/a-tree/h/Hsin:Lin_Hsin.html DBLP] === Digital music === * "Rudiments Mapping – An Axiomatic revision.text:
{{italic title}} [[File:Federico Barocci - La Madonna del Gatto.jpg|thumb|''Madonna del Gatto'']] The painting titled '''''Madonna of the Cat''''' or '''''Madonna del gatto''''' was painted in 1575 by [[Federico Barocci]]. It is presently in the [[National Gallery|National Gallery of London]].
==History and Description== The painting was made for Count Antonio Brancaleoni of [[Perugia]]. Engravings of the painting appeared by 1577.
The Holy Family, consisting of [[Saint Joseph|Joseph]], Mary, a young [[John the Baptist]], and a lactating infant Jesus, are portrayed in a domestic moment. John appears to be teasing the cat with a captured goldfinch, an allegoric symbol of Christ's Passion. John's reed rests against a wall in the background. The main characters form a proto-[[Baroque art|Baroque]]-style diagonal to the right. In the style of Barocci, the cheeks are rosy.<ref>[http://www.nationalgallery.org.uk/paintings/federico-barocci-the-madonna-of-the-cat-la-madonna-del-gatto The Madonna of the Cat ('La Madonna del Gatto')], website of the National Gallery, London.</ref>
==References== {{reflist}}
{{DEFAULTSORT:Madonna of the Cat (Barocci)}} [[Category:1570s paintings]] [[Category:Italian paintings]] [[Category:Collections of the National Gallery, London]] [[Category:Paintings of the Madonna and Child]] [[Category:Birds in art]] [[Category:Cats in art]] [[Category:Saint Joseph in art]]

<!-- Image with inadequate rationale removed: [[File:Radiantbaby.png|right|thumb|Haring's ''Radiant Baby'']] -->
'''Neo-pop''' is a [[postmodern art]]<ref>Fred S. Kleiner, Helen Gardner, Christin J. Mamiya, Richard G. Tansey, ''Gardner's Art Through the Ages: Chapters 19-34'', Thomson Wadsworth, 2004, p1068. {{ISBN|0-534-64091-5}}</ref> movement of the 1980s. The term refers to artists influenced by [[pop art]] and pop culture imagery, such as [[Jeff Koons]]<ref>Peter Childs, Mike Storry, ''Encyclopedia of Contemporary British Culture'', Taylor & Francis, 1999, p413. {{ISBN|0-415-14726-3}}</ref>, but also artists working in graffiti and cartoon art, such as [[Keith Haring]].<ref>{{Cite web |url=http://www.glbtqarchive.com/arts |title=Index of /arts |website=www.glbtqarchive.com |access-date=2018-06-03}}</ref> Japanese artist [[Takashi Murakami]] is described as the first of the Japanese neo-pop artists to "break the ice in terms of recycling Japanese pop culture".<ref>Smith, Roberta. "From a mushroom cloud, a burst of art reflecting Japan’s psyche." ''New York Times'' 8, no. 04 (2005): B28.</ref> Japanese neo-pop is associated with the [[otaku]] subculture and the obsessive interests in anime, manga and other forms of pop culture. Artists such as [[Kenji Yanobe]] exemplify this approach to art and [[fandom]].<ref>Munroe, Alexandra. "Introducing Little Boy.” In ''Little Boy: The Arts of Japan’s Exploding Subcultures'', edited by Takashi Murakami. pp. 241–61. Exh. cat. New York: Japan Society; New Haven: Yale University Press, 2005.</ref> 

== See also ==
* [[Superflat]]

==References==
{{Reflist}}

{{DEFAULTSORT:Neo-Pop}}

revision.text:
{{Infobox company | name = Not Just A Label (NJAL) | logo = NOT_JUST_A_LABEL_Logo.png | type = [[Public Company|Public]] | traded_as = NJAL | industry = Fashion | founded = {{start date|2008}} | founder = Stefan Siegel
Daniel Siegel | hq_location_city = [[London]] | hq_location_country = [[United Kingdom]] | area_served = Worldwide | owner = [[Stefan Siegel]] | website = {{URL|www.notjustalabel.com}} | footnotes = }} '''Not Just A Label''' ('''NJAL''') is a London-based global sales platform, virtual showroom and online community that connects independent designers to consumers.{{cite web | url = https://thenextweb.com/insider/2012/05/05/behind-the-design-an-interview-with-not-just-a-label/ | title = Behind the design: An interview with Not Just a Label | publisher = The Next Web | date = 5 May 2012 | accessdate = 15 February 2015 | author = Boyd Myers, Courtney }}{{cite web | url = https://www.independent.co.uk/life-style/fashion/news/london-fashion-week-how-the-internet-has-helped-break-the-big-name-monopoly-9729905.html | title = London Fashion Week: How the internet has helped break the big name monopoly | publisher = The Independent | date = 12 September 2014 | accessdate = 15 February 2015 | author = Burrell, Ian }} Products listed are locally produced with sustainability in mind{{cite web | url = http://i-d.vice.com/pl/article/czy-moda-moze-ocalic-swiat | title = czy moda może ocalić świat? | publisher = i-D Vice | date = 10 September 2014 | accessdate = 15 February 2015 | language = Norwegian }} keeping in-line with the [[slow fashion]] movement.{{cite web | url = http://www.high50.com/style/what-slow-fashion-means-to-me-and-why-i-choose-to-wear-my-values | title = Sustainability: What slow fashion means to me and why I choose to wear my values | publisher = High 50 Style | date = 16 January 2015 | accessdate = 15 February 2015 | author = Robert, Christina }}{{cite web | url = http://www.wonderlandmagazine.com/2012/05/not-just-a-label-stefan-siegel/| title = Not Just a Label | publisher = Wonderland Magazine | date = 23 May 2012 |accessdate = 15 February 2015 | author = Mahanty, Shannon }} In 2014, NJAL hosted approximately 16,000 fashion designers.{{cite web | url = http://www.fashionunited.co.uk/fashion-news/design/not-just-a-label-launches-new-website-2014080421916 | title = Not Just A Label launches new website | publisher = Fashion United | date = 4 August 2014 | accessdate = 15 February 2015 }}{{cite web | url = http://www.ft.com/intl/cms/s/0/e9eefd2c-279f-11e4-be5a-00144feabdc0.html#axzz3QhKbPm5a | title = Technology for Fashion | publisher = Financial Times | date = 26 August 2014 | accessdate = 15 February 2015 | author = Moules, Jonathan }}{{cite web | url = http://monocle.com/radio/shows/the-entrepreneurs/ | title = The Entrepreneurs | publisher = Monocle | accessdate = 15 February 2015 }} NJAL is known for launching the careers of designers such as [[Mary Katrantzou]] and [[Damir Doma]]{{cite web | url = https://www.nytimes.com/2010/09/20/fashion/20iht-rcoop.html?_r=0 | title = Taking a Chance on Talent | publisher = The New York Times | date = 19 September 2010 | accessdate = 15 February 2015 | author = Britten, Fleur }} and has support from celebrities such as [[Lara Stone]], [[Lady Gaga]], [[Vivienne Westwood]] and [[Beyoncé]].{{cite web | url = http://legacy.graziadaily.co.uk/fashion/archive/2009/11/20/njal-celeb-christmas.htm | title = NJAL celeb Christmas! | publisher = Grazia Daily | date = 20 November 2009 | accessdate = 15 February 2015}} ==History== In 2008, Stefan Siegel and his brother Daniel founded NJAL as a networking platform for fashion designers.{{cite web | url = http://issuu.com/whatdesigncando/docs/wdcd12_book_web_issuu| title = The Connecting Forces of Design | publisher = WDCD | year = 2012 | accessdate = 15 February 2015}} NJAL launched "The Shop" section of their website in 2009, making it the first e-commerce site to allow consumers to buy directly from designers. ''Grazia Daily'' reported that items in "The Shop" were curated by celebrities including [[Amanda Lepore]] and [[Lara Stone]].{{cite web | url = http://www.elle.com/fashion/news/a2636/london-fashion-news-lara-stone-matches-2110/| title = London Fashion News: Lara Stone and Matches | publisher = Elle | date = 25 August 2009 | accessdate = 15 February 2015 | author = }} For the Spring/Summer 2010 season, NJAL released a limited edition offering of organic cotton T-shirts and tank tops featuring signature designs and prints of designers.{{cite web | url = http://www.thediscerningbrute.com/tag/not-just-a-label/| title = Not Just a Label: Exclusive Organic Collection | publisher = The Doscerning Brute | date = 17 June 2010 |accessdate = 15 February 2015 }} In 2011, NJAL collaborated with Spanish label [[Mango (clothing)|Mango]] in a competition where young designers presented collections at the 'El Botón' Mango Fashion Awards with NJAL supervising competitors. The same year, the site won the [[Drapers]] Etail Award for Best E-Commerce innovation.{{cite news | title = Curated By NJAL | publisher = Highs Nobiety | author = Reeve, Georgia }} NJAL first collaborated with the [[British Council]] in 2011 for the "London Meets Beirut" seminar.{{cite web | url = http://mycake.org/london-meets-beirut-innovation-in-the-design-industry/ | title = London meets Beirut: Innovation in the design industry | publisher = My Cake | date = 30 November 2011 | accessdate = 15 February 2015 | author = Davies, Lauren }} In March 2012, NJAL received a grant from the British Council to travel to India during Lakmé Fashion Week in order to develop business relationships in the country.{{cite web | url = http://creativeconomy.britishcouncil.org/people/stefan-siegel/ | title = Stefan Siegel | publisher = British Council| accessdate = 15 February 2015 }} In 2012, NJAL participated in a three-week tour of Eastern European fashion weeks where the company delivered workshops and scouted talent in [[Bratislava]], [[Kiev]], [[Łódź]], [[Belgrade]] and [[Riga]]. The trips were documented through a partnership with [[Vogue Italia]].{{cite web | url = http://www.vogue.it/en/talents/news/2012/10/eastern-europe-diary-1 | title = Eastern Europe Diary 1 | publisher = Vogue Italia | date = 18 October 2012 | accessdate = 15 February 2015}}{{cite web | url = http://www.vogue.it/en/talents/news/2012/11/eastern-europe-diary-2 | title = Eastern Europe Diary 2 | publisher = Vogue Italia | date = 2 November 2012 | accessdate = 15 February 2015 }} The same year, online-trend analysis and research service [[WGSN]] offered NJAL designers services at a 98 percent discount in order to support young talent while expanding the WGSN professional network.{{cite web | url = http://www.fashionotes.com/content/2012/05/not-just-a-label-partners-with-wgsn/ | title = Not Just A Label Partners With WGSN | publisher = Fashionotes | date = 24 May 2012 | accessdate = 15 February 2015 | author = Bailie, Lauren }}{{cite web | url = http://insidefmm.com/2012/05/not-just-a-label-offers-nearly-free-trend-service-this-month/ | title = Not Just A Label Offers Nearly-Free Trend Service This Month | publisher = Inside FMM | date = May 2012 | accessdate = 15 February 2015 }} NJAL began The Open Source Partnership with [[Vivienne Westwood]] in 2013. NJAL advised the fashion house on expanding their e-commerce business and creating a new open-source website for Westwood. In turn, Westwood became a major investor in the platform.{{cite news | title = Sechs Jahre Im Leben | publisher = Das Magazin | language = German }}{{cite news | title = Alt(r)a Moda | publisher = Ci | author = Damaggio, Marika }}{{cite news | title = Wir tauschen die Marke durch die Story aus | publisher = Form Magazin}} NJAL collaborated with the Who's Next fashion trade show in 2013 to create "The Future of Fashion" program where twenty emerging designers competed for the chance to show their designs during the Who's Next Autumn/Winter [[Paris]] trade show. Selected designers showed their collections at the 2014 Who's Next show with Siegel as one of the judges of the competition.{{cite web | url = http://www.fashionunited.co.uk/fashion-news/design/whos-next-and-not-just-a-label-launch-new-program-2013112819240 | title = Who's Next and Not Just A Label launch new program | publisher = Fashion United | date = 28 November 2013 |accessdate = 15 February 2015 }} In 2014, NJAL partnered with Matteo Marzotto and the Fiera di Vicenza center to hold the company's first offline event called "Origin Passion & Beliefs." 100 NJAL designers participated in order to showcase their wares and network with others in the fashion industry.{{cite web | url = http://www.businessoffashion.com/2014/05/matteo-marzotto-joins-just-label-unite-fashion-jewellery.html | title = Matteo Marzotto Joins with Not Just a Label to Unite Fashion and Jewellery | publisher = The Business of Fashion | date = 21 May 2014 | accessdate = 15 February 2015 | author = Kansara, Vikram Alexei }}{{cite web | url = http://www.ft.com/intl/cms/s/2/3def5f6e-8f3b-11e3-be85-00144feab7de.html#axzz3QhKbPm5a | title = Matteo Marzotto reveals his plans to revitalise his country’s gold industry | publisher = Financial Times | date = 26 March 2014 | accessdate = 15 February 2015 | author = Sanderson, Rachel }}{{cite web | url = http://www.notjustalabel.com/sites/default/files/pressfiles/167585/vogue_italia_on_origin_notjustalabel_1389358678.pdf | title = Origin Passion & Beliefs | publisher = Vogue Italia | date = 21 April 2014 | accessdate = 15 February 2015 }} The same year, NJAL was the only international platform to attend Ukrainian Fashion Week during the [[2014–15 Russian military intervention in Ukraine|political turbulence]] occurring at the time.{{cite web | url = http://mbkievfashiondays.com/en/news/v-kiev-edet-progressivnyiy-london-v-litse-osnovatelya-not-just-a-lable/| title = The Founder of Not Just a Label Will Give A Public Talk In Kiev | publisher = Mercedes-Benz Kiev Fashion Days |accessdate = 15 February 2015 }}{{cite web | url = http://uacrisis.org/ukrainian-fashion-week-stands-against-war/| title = Ukrainian Fashion Week Stands Against War | publisher = Ukraine Crisis Media Center | date = 22 March 2014 | accessdate = 15 February 2015 }}{{cite web | url = https://blogs.wsj.com/emergingeurope/2014/03/20/couturiers-undeterred-by-crisis-at-ukraine-fashion-week/| title = Couturiers Undeterred by Crisis at Ukraine Fashion Week | publisher = The Wall Street Journal | date = 20 March 2014 | accessdate = 15 February 2015 | author = Mesco, Manuela }} NJAL curated and managed the launch of the [[AEG]] produced documentary "The Next Black" about the future of textiles. The film was released in conjunction with the release of new high efficiency [[washing machines]].{{cite news | title = 10 choses quivont revolutionner la mode | publisher = Elle | date = September 2014 | language = French}} At the 2014 Copenhagen Fashion Summit, NJAL presented plans for the "Re-start Fashion" initiative, developed to help designers solve ecological challenges in the fashion industry through sustainable design.{{cite web | url = http://www.ecofashionworld.com/Events/Copenhagen-Fashion-Summit-The-Anatomy-of-Sustainable-Fashion.html | title = Copenhagen Fashion Summit: The Anatomy of Sustainable Fashion | publisher = Eco Fashion World | date = 8 May 2014 | accessdate = 15 February 2015 | author = Locskai, Nora }}{{cite web | url = http://www.copenhagenfashionsummit.com/video | title = Restart Fashion - 5 Easy steps by Connie Nielsen, Stefan Siegel and Jonas Eder-Hansen | publisher = Copenhagen Fashion Summit | accessdate = 15 February 2015 }} NJAL relaunched its site in 2014 in order to make it more user-compatible on smart phones and tablets as well as desktops.{{cite web | url = http://www.femalefirst.co.uk/lifestyle-fashion/stylenews/not-just-a-label-hand-picked-luxury-fashion-511519.html| title = Not Just A Label launches website for hand-picked luxury fashion | publisher = Female First | date = 31 July 2014 |accessdate = 15 February 2015 | author = Davies, Taryn }} While the e-commerce part of the site was established in 2009, the 2014 relaunch made sales the main component of the site.{{cite web | url = http://www.stylebubble.co.uk/style_bubble/2014/08/a-new-njal.html| title = A New NJAL | publisher = Style Bubble | date = 1 August 2014 |accessdate = 15 February 2015 }} The relaunch also incorporated an open source [[content management system]] into the site which allows designers to edit their own profiles. ===Notable designers and celebrity clients=== Notable designers who showcased early on with NJAL include [[Mary Katrantzou]], [[Damir Doma]] and [[Rad Hourani]].{{cite web | url = http://howtospendit.ft.com/style/4222-where-to-spot-fashions-next-big-thing| title = Where to spot fashion's next big thing | publisher = How To Spend It | date = 5 April 2011 | accessdate = 15 February 2015 | author = Macpherson, Lindsay }} Celebrities who have purchased items from designers showcased on NJAL include [[Rihanna]], [[Lady Gaga]], [[Alice Dellal]], [[Pixie Geldof]], [[Paris Hilton]], [[Taylor Swift]], [[Katie Holmes]], [[Whitney Houston]], [[Fergie (singer)|Fergie]], [[Elle Mcpherson]] and [[Beyoncé]].{{cite web | url = http://insidefmm.com/2010/09/not-just-a-label-supporting-avant-garde-fashion-designers/| title = Not Just A Label: Supporting Avant-garde Fashion Designers | publisher = Inside FMM |accessdate = 15 February 2015 }} ==Business model== NJAL is a platform for designers, buyers, press and consumers to collaborate with each other independently.{{cite web | url = http://design.britishcouncil.org/blog/2014/nov/02/not-just-label-skopje/| title = Not Just a Label at Skopje | publisher = British Council | date = 2 November 2014 |accessdate = 15 February 2015 | author = Lean, Marion }}{{cite web | url = http://www.martinez-ribes.com/en/will-there-be-a-revolution/ | title = WILL THERE BE A REVOLUTION? Not Just a Label, an alternative in fashion retail | publisher = Martinez-Ribes | date = 9 September 2014 | accessdate = 15 February 2015 }} The company does not buy stock from designers, but rather takes 30 percent of all sales with prices set by the designer. Representatives from NJAL visit fashion week events, institutions, showrooms and studios looking for emerging designers with established look-books before providing exposure via editorial coverage and social media. Designers are also able to approach NJAL independently. Limited-edition collections and [[bespoke]] pieces are assessed by NJAL staff before listed on the site. In addition to the retail shop, the NJAL site contains a designer directory indexed alphabetically as well as by country, womenswear, menswear, shoes, bags, accessories, jewellery and organic products. NJAL also acts as an agency that collaborates with large corporations and governments to create and manage partnerships that promote ethical fashion. ==See also== *[[Stefan Siegel]] ==References== {{Reflist|30em}} ==External links== *[http://www.notjustalabel.com Official website] [[Category:Fashion websites]] [[Category:Fashion organizations]] [[Category:Fashion design]] [[Category:Online clothing retailers]] [[Category:Retail companies established in 2009]]

[[File:Pittore di dolon, cratere lucano a figure rosse, con ulisse che consulta lo spirito di tiresia e giud. di paride, 380 ac. ca 01.JPG|thumb|Odysseus in the Underworld Krater<ref>{{Citation|last=Dolon|first=English: Dolon PainterFrançais : Peintre de|title=English: Odysseus consulting the shade of Tiresias. Side A from a Lucanian red-figured calyx-krater, 4th century BC.|url=https://commons.wikimedia.org/wiki/File:Odysseus_Tiresias_Cdm_Paris_422_n2.jpg|accessdate=2017-12-04}}</ref>]] The '''Odysseus in the Underworld krater''' is a Lucanian kalyx-[[krater]] decorated in the [[Red-figure pottery|red-figure]] style dating to ca. 380 BC - ca. 360 BC.<ref name=":0">{{Cite web|url=http://www.perseus.tufts.edu/hopper/artifact?name=Paris%2C+Cab.+M%26%23233%3Bd.+422&object=Vase|title=Paris, Cab. Méd. 422 (Vase)|last=|first=|date=|website=|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=}}</ref> It was found in Pisticci, south Italy and is believed to be the work of the Dolon painter, a famous Lucanian red-figure vase painter who worked in the Metaponto workshop and had a particular affinity for large krateres and mythological scenes.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.britishmuseum.org/research/search_the_collection_database/term_details.aspx?bioId=96910|title=Term details|website=British Museum|access-date=2017-12-04}}</ref> The krater is now at the Bibliothèque Nationale in Paris.<ref name=":0" />
== Measurements == The kalyx-krater used measures at 48.4 cm in height and 49.8 cm in diameter. It has a pair of curved handles emerging from the lower body of the vessel and sprouting outward to the lip.<ref name=":1">{{Cite web|url=https://repositories.lib.utexas.edu/bitstream/handle/2152/31743/CARDIFF-THESIS-2015.pdf?sequence=1|title=Drinking with the Dead: Odyssean Nekuomanteia and Sympotic Sophrosyne in Classical Greek Vase Painting|last=Cardiff III|first=Hal Victor|date=May 2015|website=|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=}}</ref>
== Depictions == [[File:Odysseus Tiresias Cdm Paris 422.jpg|thumb|Odysseus, seated between Eurylochos and Perimedes, consulting the shade of Tiresias; to left Eurylochos wearing pilos and chlamys. Side A from a Lucanian red-figured calyx-krater.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://commons.wikimedia.org/wiki/Category:Dolon_Painter#/media/File:Pittore_di_dolon,_cratere_lucano_a_figure_rosse,_con_ulisse_che_consulta_lo_spirito_di_tiresia_e_giud._di_paride,_380_ac._ca_01.JPG |title=Category:Dolon Painter - Wikimedia Commons|website=commons.wikimedia.org|language=en|access-date=2017-12-04}}</ref>]] [[File:Judgement of Paris Dolon Painter CdM Paris DeRidder422 n1.jpg|thumb|Hermes (on the left) asking Paris to arbitrate the contest between Athena, Aphrodite and Hera. Detail, side B from a Lucanian red-figured calyx-krater. <ref>{{Citation|last=Dolon|first=English: Dolon PainterFrançais : Peintre de|title=English: Hermes (on the left) asking Paris to arbitrate the contest between Athena, Aphrodite and Hera. Detail, side B from a Lucanian red-figured calyx-krater, ca. 380 BC.|url=https://commons.wikimedia.org/wiki/File:Judgement_of_Paris_Dolon_Painter_CdM_Paris_DeRidder422_n1.jpg|accessdate=2017-12-04}}</ref>]]
=== A side === The A-side scene on the belly of the kalyx-krater depicts Homer's story of Odysseus's visit to the Underworld to consult the dead seer Teiresias. This meeting is known as a nekuomanteion or "consultation with the dead".<ref name=":1" />
Odysseus is seated in the middle of the scene on uneven ground; he is seated between Eurylochos, second-in-command of Odysseus' ship during the return to Ithaca after the Trojan War, and Perimedes, one of [[Odysseus]]'s companions during his return voyage from [[Troy]], awaiting the consultation with the ghost of Teiresias. Odyseus is wearing boots and has a short sword in his right hand. There are two dead rams directly underneath Oddyseus's sword, a sacrifice needed to summon the dead for ghosts cannot speak until they have drunk blood.<ref>{{Cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=BmmW1h7Qk7MC&pg=PA212&lpg=PA212&dq=Odysseus+and+Tiresias+in+the+Underworld+krater&source=bl&ots=qW5l16zNE-&sig=xR8rH9F-s3rWavwDGzU8la1FZCA&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwjk5N3AlKHXAhUKOiYKHZAuBBcQ6AEIWzAO#v=onepage&q=Odysseus%20and%20Tiresias%20in%20the%20Underworld%20krater&f=false|title=The Art of Vase-Painting in Classical Athens|last=Robertson|first=Martin|date=1992|publisher=Cambridge University Press|isbn=9780521338813|language=en}}</ref>
=== B side === The scene on the B-side of the krater depicts the judgment of Paris where Hermes (on left) asks Paris, the Trojan prince, to arbitrate the contest between Aphrodite, Hera, and Athena and determine who is the most beautiful. The scene is so well detailed that many scholars describe the krater as having a “double A-side”.<ref name=":1" />
== See also == * [[Death in ancient Greek art]]
== References == {{reflist}}
[[Category:Ancient Greek pottery]] [[Category:Odyssey]] [[Category:4th-century BC works]]

The '''One Dimension Group''' (''Al Bu'd al Wahad'') was a modern art group founded in Iraq, by [[Shakir Hassan Al Said]] in 1971 which attempted to combine medieval [[Sufism|Sufi]] traditions with contemporary, abstract art. Although the One Dimension Group was founded in Iraq, its members originated from across Arab nations, and its influence was felt across the Arab art world.
==Background==
One Dimension is one of a number of [[Iraqi art#Art groups|art groups]] that formed in 20th-century Iraq. During the first world war, a small group of European officers and artists settled in Iraq, exposing young artists to Western art traditions and techniques. <ref>Davis, E., ''Memories of State: Politics, History, and Collective Identity in Modern Iraq,'' University of California Press, 2005, p. 82</ref> While local artists and middle classes developed an appreciation for European art, the arts community searched for ways of synthesising indigenous art with international trends. In effect, these groups were seeking to forge an Arabic art aesthetic and to use art to help their nations reassert a sense of national identity. <ref>Ulrike al-Khamis, “An Historical Overview 1900s-1990s,” in: Maysaloun, F. (ed.), ''Strokes of Genius: Contemporary Iraqi Art,'' London:, Saqi Books, 2001, p. 25; Baram, A., ''Culture, History and Ideology in the Formation of Ba'thist Iraq,1968-89,'' Springer, 1991, pp 70-71</ref>
Between the 1930s and the early 1970s, more than six different art groups were formed: ''The Pioneers'' formed in the 1930s;<ref>Sabrah,S.A. and Ali, M.," ''Iraqi Artwork Red List: A Partial List of the Artworks Missing from the National Museum of Modern Art, Baghdad,'' Iraq, 2010, pp 7-9</ref> ''The Avantgarde Group'' formed in 1950; <ref>Ulrike al-Khamis, “An Historical Overview 1900s-1990s,” in: Maysaloun, F. (ed.), ''Strokes of Genius: Contemporary Iraqi Art,'' London:, Saqi Books, 2001, p. 25</ref>; ''[[Iraqi art#Jama’et Baghdad lil Fenal-Hadith (The Baghdad Modern Art Group)|The Baghdad Modern Art Group]]'' formed in 1951; <ref>Baram, A., ''Culture, History and Ideology in the Formation of Ba'thist Iraq,1968-89,'' Springer, 1991, pp 70-71</ref> ''The Impressionists'' formed in 1953;<ref>Shabout, N., "Ghosts of Futures Past: Iraqi Culture in a State of Suspension," in Denise Robinson, ''Through the Roadbloacks: Realities in Raw Motion,'' [Conference Reader], School of Fine Arts, Cyprus University, 23–25 November</ref> ''The Corners Group'' founded in 1961;<ref>Ghareeb, E.A. and Dougherty, B., ''Historical Dictionary of Iraq,'' Scarecrow Press, 2004, p. 174</ref> ''The Innovationists'' founded in 1963;<ref>Dabrowska, K. and Hann, G., ''Iraq Then and Now: A Guide to the Country and Its People,'' Bradt Travel Guides, 2008, p. 279</ref> ''The New Vision'' founded in 1968 and ''One Dimension'' founded in 1971.<ref>Flood, F.B. and Necipoglu, G. (eds) ''A Companion to Islamic Art and Architecture,'' Wiley, 2017, p. 1294</ref>. Some of these groups endured for decades, while others were short-lived and abandoned within a few years of their formation. <ref>Sabrah,S.A. and Ali, M.," ''Iraqi Artwork Red List: A Partial List of the Artworks Missing from the National Museum of Modern Art, Baghdad,'' Iraq, 2010, pp 7-9; Lack, J., ''Why Are We 'Artists'?: 100 World Art Manifestos, Penguin, 2017, [E-book edition], n.p. See section M12</ref>
Each of these groups developed different ideas about how to combine heritage and modernity and developed a different vision for a national art aesthetic. Although there were tensions in the different visions of these groups,<ref>Al-Khalil, S. and Makiya, K., ''The Monument: Art, Vulgarity, and Responsibility in Iraq,'' University of California Press, 1991, p. 79 -80</ref> collectively, they actively searched for new national vision which would enable the country to develop internally, as well as take its place on a world stage.<ref>Al-Ali, N. and Al-Najjar, D., ''We Are Iraqis: Aesthetics and Politics in a Time of War,'' Syracuse University Press, 2013, p. 22</ref>
Of these art groups, the Baghdad Modern Art Group and the One Dimension Group are the most frequently cited.
==Brief history and philosophy== The One Dimension Group was established formally in 1971 by the prominent Baghdadi artist and intellectual, Shakir Hassan Al Said, when he published a manifesto for the group.<ref>The manifesto was published in the Iraqi newspaper, ''al-Jamhuriyyah,'' issue no. 880, p. 8; See: Shabout, N.,"Shakir Hassan Al Said: Time and Space in the Work of the Iraqi Artist - A Journey Towards One Dimension," ''Nafas Art Magazine,'' May, 2008, [https://universes.art/nafas/articles/2008/shakir-hassan-al-said/ Online:]</ref> Al Said had previously been a founding member of the Baghdad Group for Modern Art (Jama'at Baghdad lil-Fann al-Hadith) together with [[Jawad Saleem]] (1919-1961) and [[Jabra Ibrahim Jabra]] (1919-1994), but he along with several high profile artists, had withdrawn from that group when it lost its sense of direction, following the death of its founder, Jawad Saleem in 1961.<ref>Ali, W., ''Modern Islamic Art: Development and Continuity,'' University of Florida Press, 1997, pp 51-52</ref>
The One Dimension manifesto gives voice to the group's commitment to both heritage and modernity and sought to distance itself from the modern Arab artists which they perceived as following European artistic traditions.<ref>Mejcher-Atassi, S., "Shakir Hassan Al Said," in ''Mathaf Encyclopedia of Modern Art and the Arab World,'' Online: http://www.encyclopedia.mathaf.org.qa/en/bios/Pages/Shakir-Hassan-Al-Said.aspx</ref> One Dimension's objectives are complex and sophisticated; it is philosophy, technique, style and a relationship between time and space, between the visual and the non-visual.<ref>Shabout, N.M., ''Modern Arab Art: Formation of Arab Aesthetics,'' University of Florida Press, 2007, p. 109M</ref> The "one dimension" is an oblique reference to [[Sufism]], which has been described as "the inner dimension of [[Islam]]."<ref>Titus Burckhardt, ''Art of Islam: Language and Meaning'' (Bloomington: World Wisdom, 2009), p. 223</ref> The objectives of the One Dimension Group were multi-dimensional and complex. At the most basic level, the group rejected two and three-two dimensional artwork in favour of a single "inner dimension". This approach was influenced by both the philosophy of [[Martin Heidegger]] and the traditions of [[Arabic calligraphy]] and associated [[Sufi]] movements. In practice, a single inner dimension was difficult to realise because most artworks are produced on two-dimensional surfaces.<ref>Lack, J., ''Why Are We 'Artists'?: 100 World Art Manifestos, Penguin, 2017, [E-book edition], n.p. See section M52; Shabout, N.M., ''Modern Arab Art: Formation of Arab Aesthetics,'' University of Florida Press, 2007, p. 109</ref> At a more profound level, one dimension refers to "eternity".<ref>Shabout, N.,"Shakir Hassan Al Said: Time and Space in the Work of the Iraqi Artist - A Journey Towards One Dimension," ''Nafas Art Magazine,'' May, 2008, [https://universes.art/nafas/articls/2008/shakir-hassan-al-said/ Online:]; also see Shabout, N.M., ''Modern Arab Art: Formation of Arab Aesthetics,'' University of Florida Press, 2007, p. 109</ref>Al Said explained:<ref>Cited in: Shabout, N.,"Shakir Hassan Al Said: Time and Space in the Work of the Iraqi Artist - A Journey Towards One Dimension," ''Nafas Art Magazine,'' May, 2008, [https://universes.art/nafas/articls/2008/shakir-hassan-al-said/ Online:]</ref>
{{blockquote|"From a philosophical point of view, the One-Dimension is eternity, or an extension of the past to the time before the existence of pictorial surface; to the non-surface. Our consciousness of the world is a relative presence. It is our self-existence while our absence is our eternal presence." }}
Al Said actively searched for relationships between time and space; and for a visual language that would connect Iraq's deep art traditions with modern art methods and materials. The incorporation of callij (calligraphy) letters into modern artworks was an important aspect of this relationship. The letter became part of Al Said's transition from figurative art to abstract art.<ref>Shabout, N.,"Shakir Hassan Al Said: Time and Space in the Work of the Iraqi Artist - A Journey Towards One Dimension," ''Nafas Art Magazine,'' May, 2008, [https://universes.art/nafas/articles/2008/shakir-hassan-al-said/ Online:]</ref> Arabic calligraphy was charged with intellectual and esoteric Sufi meaning,<ref>Flood, F.B. and Necipoglu, G. (eds) ''A Companion to Islamic Art and Architecture,'' Wiley, 2017, pp 1294-95</ref> in that it was an explicit reference to a Medieval theology where letters were seen as primordial signifiers and manipulators of the cosmos.<ref>Mir-Kasimov, O., ''Words of Power: Hurufi Teachings Between Shi'ism and Sufism in Medieval Islam,'' I.B. Tauris and the Institute of Ismaili Studies, 2015</ref>
Al Said, and members of the One Dimension group, searched for a new artistic identity, drawn from within their own culture and heritage and successfully integrated Islamic visual traditions, especially calligraphy and Arabic motifs, into contemporary, abstract compositions.<ref>Lindgren, A. and Ross, S., ''The Modernist World,'' Routledge, 2015, p. 495; Mavrakis, N., "The Hurufiyah Art Movement in Middle Eastern Art," ''McGill Journal of Middle Eastern Studies Blog,'' Online: https://mjmes.wordpress.com/2013/03/08/article-5/; Tuohy, A. and Masters, C., ''A-Z Great Modern Artists,'' Hachette UK, 2015, p. 56</ref> At an individual level, these artists were carrying out their own dialogue with national identity and modern art, at a broader level they also worked towards an aesthetic that transcended national boundaries and represented a broader affiliation with an Arab identity.<ref>Flood, F.B. and Necipoglu, G. (eds) ''A Companion to Islamic Art and Architecture,'' Wiley, 2017, p. 1294; Mejcher-Atassi, S., "Shakir Hassan Al Said," in ''Mathaf Encyclopedia of Modern Art and the Arab World,'' Online: http://www.encyclopedia.mathaf.org.qa/en/bios/Pages/Shakir-Hassan-Al-Said.aspx</ref> Al Said and his group successfully bridged the gap between modernity and heritage.<ref>Dabrowska, K. and Hann, G., ''Iraq: The Ancient Sites and Iraqi Kurdistan,'' Bradt Travel Guides, 2015, p. 30</ref> In so doing, they "charted a new Arabo-Islamic art aesthetic, and thus initiated a possible alternative for art valuating for local and regional art other than those allowed through an exclusionary Western canon of art history."<ref>Shabout, N.,"Shakir Hassan Al Said: Time and Space in the Work of the Iraqi Artist - A Journey Towards One Dimension," ''Nafas Art Magazine,'' May, 2008, [https://universes.art/nafas/articles/2008/shakir-hassan-al-said/ Online:]</ref>
In focusing on the Arabic letter as the central element of his work, al-Said soon was collaborating with [[Madiha Omar]] (who by then was living in the US) and [[Jamil Hamoudi]], who both joined his group.<ref>Lack, J., ''Why Are We 'Artists'?: 100 World Art Manifestos, Penguin, 2017, [E-book edition], n.p. See section M52</ref> The One Dimension Group was very significant to the so-called School of Calligraphic Art (also known as the [[Hurufiyya movement]]) which comprised groups of artists that had emerged independently across North Africa and the Middle East in the second half of the 20th century, with the common thread being that each group searched for ways to integrate tradition and modernity in a way that would contributed to a distinct national style.<ref>Ali, W., ''Modern Islamic Art: Development and Continuity,'' University of Florida Press, 1997, p. 52; Dadi. I., "Ibrahim El Salahi and Calligraphic Modernism in a Comparative Perspective," ''South Atlantic Quarterly,'' 109 (3), 2010 pp 555-576, DOI:https://doi.org/10.121500382876-2010-006; Flood, F.B. and Necipoglu, G. (eds) ''A Companion to Islamic Art and Architecture,'' Wiley, 2017, p. 1294 </ref>
Although each of these groups developed locally, and went by different labels at the local level, collectively, these groups and their practitioners would become known as the School of Calligraphy (or [[Hurufiyya movement]]).<ref>Dadi. I., "Ibrahim El Salahi and Calligraphic Modernism in a Comparative Perspective," ''South Atlantic Quarterly,'' 109 (3), 2010 pp 555-576, DOI:https://doi.org/10.121500382876-2010-006; Flood, F.B. and Necipoglu, G. (eds) ''A Companion to Islamic Art and Architecture,'' Wiley, 2017, p. 1294 </ref> In Jordan, the movement emerged in the 1950s and was known as the ''Al-hurufiyyah movement'',<ref>Mavrakis, N., "The Hurufiyah Art Movement in Middle Eastern Art," ''McGill Journal of Middle Eastern Studies Blog,'' Online: https://mjmes.wordpress.com/2013/03/08/article-5/;Tuohy, A. and Masters, C., ''A-Z Great Modern Artists,'' Hachette UK, 2015, p. 56; Dadi. I., "Ibrahim El Salahi and Calligraphic Modernism in a Comparative Perspective," ''South Atlantic Quarterly,'' 109 (3), 2010 pp 555-576, DOI:https://doi.org/10.121500382876-2010-006</ref> while in Iraq, the movement was known as ''Al Bu'd al Wahad'' (or the One Dimension Group)",<ref>"Shaker Hassan Al Said," Darat al Funum, Online: www.daratalfunun.org/main/activit/curentl/anniv/exhib3.html; Flood, F.B. and Necipoglu, G. (eds) ''A Companion to Islamic Art and Architecture,'' Wiley, 2017, p. 1294 </ref> and in Iran, the [[Iranian modern and contemporary art#Saqqakhaneh movement|Saqqa-Khaneh movement]].<ref>Flood, F.B. and Necipoglu, G. (eds) ''A Companion to Islamic Art and Architecture,'' Wiley, 2017, p. 1294</ref> In Sudan, artworks took on a slightly different form - since artists rejected Western art traditions and included both Islamic calligraphy and West African motifs.<ref>Flood, F.B. and Necipoglu, G. (eds) ''A Companion to Islamic Art and Architecture,'' Wiley, 2017, p. 1298-1299</ref> In Sudan, the movement was known as the ''Old Khartoum School.'' <ref>Reynolds, D.R., ''The Cambridge Companion to Modern Arab Culture,'' Cambridge University Press, 2015, p. 202</ref>
Original members of the One Dimension group include: [[Rafa al-Nasiri]], [[Mohammed Ghani Hikmat]], [[Nuri al-Rawi]], [[Dia Azzawi]], [[Jamil Hamoudi]], Hashem Samarchi (b. 1939), Hashim al-Baghdadi (1917-1973) and Saad Shaker (1935-2005).<ref>Treichl, C., ''Art and Language: Explorations in (Post) Modern Thought and Visual Culture'', Kassel University Press, 2017, p.117</ref>
==See also==
* [[Arabic art]] * [[Iraqi art]] * [[Islamic art]] * [[Islamic calligraphy]] * [[Hurufiyya movement]] * [[List of Muslim painters]] * [[List of Iraqi artists]]
